thread.title_full: Riskier Borrowers Enter Euro Bond Market as Greece Concern Eases - Bloomberg Business

author: Selcuk Gokoluk
title: Riskier Borrowers Enter Euro Bond Market as Greece Concern Eases
text:
Europe’s debt markets, reinvigorated by optimism for an end to the Greek crisis, are embracing riskier borrowers.
French glass maker Verallia SA is marketing 660 million euros ($723 million) of bonds in a deal expected to be rated four levels below investment grade by Moody’s Investors Service, according to a person familiar with the matter, who isn’t authorized to speak publicly and asked not to be identified. Japanese mobile carrier SoftBank Group Corp. led the revival, selling about $4.5 billion of debt in euros and dollars in the biggest junk-bond sale since April.
Issuance of corporate bonds in Europe increased this week to 28 billion euros, the most since the five days ending June 12, as the Greek government seeks to complete negotiations on a new bailout. Lower-rated companies are joining Europe’s resurgent debt market, which also saw iPhone maker Apple Inc. marketing its first notes in pounds on Friday.
“All traffic lights are green and we are seeing transactions move through the pipeline,” said Christian Reusch, co-head of global syndication at UniCredit SpA in Munich.
French medical diagnostics company Labco S.A. and German laboratory operator Synlab Group, both acquired by buyout firm Cinven Ltd. and rated five levels below investment grade by Moody’s, sold more than 1 billion euros of notes on Thursday. Dufry AG, the Swiss operator of duty-free stores, issued 700 million euros of junk bonds the same day, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Average Yield The average yield on speculative-grade bonds in euros fell to 4.35 percent on Thursday, from an almost two-year high of 4.72 percent on July 8, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch index data.
Apple, which is rated investment grade, is seeking to sell notes due in 14 years and 27 years as part of a program of returning capital to shareholders, according to a person familiar with the matter.
The average yield on investment-grade debt in pounds is 3.39 percent, compared with 1.31 percent for those in euros and 3.34 in dollars, the Bank of America Merrill Lynch index data show.
